column1: # SOURCE: Egyptian Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources
# DESCRIPTION: Historical diesel pump prices in Egypt from 2012-2024
#   phases and currency devaluations. Prices are official government-regulated pump prices for diesel
# UNITS: usd_per_liter (USD per liter at period exchange rate)
# LOGIC: Egypt's fuel subsidy reform occurred in distinct phases:
#   Phase 2 (July 2014): First major reform - 64% price increase to EGP 1.80/L under IMF pressure
#   Phase 7 (2020-2021): Prices held stable despite oil volatility (COVID period)
#   Phase 8 (July 2022): First increase in 3 years to EGP 7.25/L (Ukraine war impact)
#   1. Exchange rates are period averages from Central Bank of Egypt / World Bank data
#   2. Dates represent effective date of price changes; prices valid until next change
#   3. Pre-2014 data interpolated from energypedia historical records
#   4. Agricultural diesel uses same pump price (no separate agricultural pricing after 2014)
#   5. Prices represent urban pump prices; may vary slightly by region
#   6. 2020-2021 prices assumed stable based on quarterly review reports showing no changes
#   - Official government-announced prices verified against multiple sources
#   - Exchange rates from Central Bank of Egypt and World Bank official data
#   - Some interpolation required for months between price announcements
#   - USD calculations derived from EGP prices and period exchange rates
# COMPARISON_TO_TOY: Toy data uses monthly granularity with modulated prices based on global oil.
#   Research data uses actual government-announced prices at change dates. Key differences:
#   - Toy: EGP 2.90-3.16 in 2015 vs Research: EGP 1.80 (subsidy still heavy)
#   - Toy: Smooth monthly variation vs Research: Step changes at policy announcements
#   - Toy: Exchange rates roughly match but not identical
#   - Research file confirms subsidy reform was more dramatic than toy assumptions
